awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Investigation of the Effects of Organic Matter and Sulfur in the Environmental Fate of Mercury
awd_abstract_narration:
Mercury is responsible for more than 80% of the fish consumption advisories in fresh waters of the United States.  Most of this mercury is released by the combustion of coal and is deposited from the atmosphere near and far from the sources.  Once deposited, the threat of mercury to food webs depends on the extent to which ionic mercury is converted to (1) methylmercury, the form of mercury that is accumulated from plankton to fish and ultimately to humans, and (2) elemental mercury, the form of mercury that is removed from aquatic systems by volatilization.  Mercury is converted to methylmercury mainly by sulfate-reducing bacteria that thrive in aquatic environments deprived of oxygen.  The ability of these bacteria to methylate mercury depends on the form of the ionic mercury -- whether or not its availability to sulfate-reducing bacteria is limited by its association with organic matter or its precipitation as mercuric sulfide minerals.  Mercury is converted to elemental mercury by reduction by a variety of processes for which the influence of organic matter association and precipitation as mercuric sulfide is not well known.  The goal of this research is to assess the role of organic matter and sulfur in influencing the conversion of ionic mercury to methylmercury, the first step in making mercury available to aquatic organisms.

The focus of this proposal is to improve understanding of the interactions between mercury, sulfur, and organic matter.  The research is driven by two main hypotheses that investigate the role of sulfur cycling and redox conditions on the reactivity of organic matter to mercury.  The first hypothesis examines the abiotic incorporation of sulfide into organic matter as a function of organic matter composition, and the role of metals on the stability of the newly-incorporated organic sulfur to oxidation.  The second hypothesis addresses the effects of the composition and redox state of organic matter on the reduction of mercury from Hg(II) to Hg(0), and inhibition of the reduction of Hg(II) by complexation to reduced sulfur groups in organic matter and inorganic sulfide.  The hypotheses will be tested by (1) examining sulfide incorporation into organic matter and reduction of Hg(II) to Hg(0) by organic matter using laboratory experiments and field studies at sites in the Florida Everglades and interior Alaska that represent a range of sulfur and organic matter conditions and (2) characterizing sulfur and mercury in these materials by X-ray absorption near-edge structure (XANES) spectroscopy.  These efforts will be enhanced by the use of electrochemistry to study coupled metal-organic matter redox reactions and high energy-resolution XANES spectroscopy to resolve sulfur functionality.  The research goals will be complemented by a high-school teacher training program focusing on the laboratory research and participation in ongoing and new science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) education efforts.

por.por_cntn:
The availability of the toxic element mercury in environmental organic materials and minerals to living organisms is largely regulated by the degree to which mercury forms chemical bonds with sulfur atoms. The strength of a mercury-sulfur bond is determined by the way in which the sulfur atom is itself chemically bonded to other atoms such as oxygen, carbon, nitrogen, and sulfur in the materials. Characterization of both the molecular forms of sulfur and its surrounding atoms and the reactivity of these sulfur forms with mercury was addressed using synchrotron spectroscopy of sulfur and mercury in natural samples of environmental organic matter, experimental reaction products, and selected organisms. Spectroscopic results were supported by results obtained with other analytical techniques and computational molecular modeling.

The main findings with respect to sulfur showed that the chemical reactivity of sulfur with mercury in dissolved natural organic matter from aquatic environments varies according to the oxidation state of the sulfur and the amounts of the different forms of sulfur in the organic matter. When there is more sulfur of a type termed thiol-sulfur that is bonded to mercury, the abiotic formation of mercury sulfide minerals occurs more quickly in the presence of oxygen. In experiments with a model thiol-sulfur compound and mercury the reaction occurred within minutes. Application to Florida Everglades samples showed that in the deeper aquatic system, dissolved organic matter contains more thiol-sulfur; however, the thiol-sulfur is altered to less reactive, more oxidized forms if brought closer to the surface in contact with oxygen from the atmosphere or exposure to sunlight.

The high-resolution spectroscopic technique used to characterize mercury bonds to different types of sulfur was also used to examine biochemical processes that affect bioavailability of mercury inside organisms. Mercury bonded to thiol-sulfur in natural organic matter, including mercury that had transformed to mercury sulfide minerals, was bioavailable to zebrafish in aquaria likely, in part, through the mediation of bacteria that broke down the mercury sulfide minerals. The mechanism of toxicity of mercury to bacteria was characterized, and a common mechanism for the demethylation of methylmercury, which is the form of mercury ingested through fish consumption, was identified for these animals: fish, an aquatic waterbird, and earthworms. The demethylation reaction mechanism involved strong mercury bonds to selenium in proteins; selenium is an element similar to sulfur.

The new knowledge of mercury-sulfur interactions in the environment was incorporated in the development and dissemination of educational content to high school teachers in the Chicago Public Schools on a separate project (NSF Award #1720856) in which students learn chemistry through investigation of contaminated soils, water, and air in their communities.  The knowledge was also used in the content of a dual-enrollment course offered to CPS high school students developed in a second project aimed at attracting more students to careers in the geosciences (NSF Award #1600508).
